segments.pli: Atha kho āyasmā rādho yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā rādho bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: Then Venerable Rādha went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:
“Sir, they speak of this thing called ‘Māra’.

segments.pli: “Rūpe kho, rādha, sati māro vā assa māretā vā yo vā pana mīyati.
segments.en: “When there is form, Rādha, there may be Māra, or the murderer, or the murdered.

segments.pli: Tasmātiha tvaṃ, rādha, rūpaṃ māroti passa, māretāti passa, mīyatīti passa, rogoti passa, gaṇḍoti passa, sallanti passa, aghanti passa, aghabhūtanti passa.
segments.en: So you should see form as Māra, the murderer, the murdered, the diseased, the abscess, the dart, the misery, the miserable.

segments.pli: Ye naṃ evaṃ passanti te sammā passanti.
segments.en: Those who see it like this see rightly.

segments.pli: viññāṇe sati māro vā assa māretā vā yo vā pana mīyati.
segments.en: consciousness, there may be Māra, or the murderer, or the murdered.

segments.pli: Tasmātiha tvaṃ, rādha, viññāṇaṃ māroti passa, māretāti passa, mīyatīti passa, rogoti passa, gaṇḍoti passa, sallanti passa, aghanti passa, aghabhūtanti passa.
segments.en: So you should see consciousness as Māra, the murderer, the murdered, the diseased, the abscess, the dart, the misery, the miserable.

segments.pli: Ye naṃ evaṃ passanti, te sammā passantī”ti.
segments.en: Those who see it like this see rightly.”
“But sir, what’s the purpose of seeing rightly?”
“Disillusionment is the purpose of seeing rightly.”
“But sir, what is the purpose of extinguishment?”

segments.pli: “Accayāsi, rādha, pañhaṃ, nāsakkhi pañhassa pariyantaṃ gahetuṃ.
segments.en: “Your question goes too far, Rādha. You couldn’t figure out the limit of questions.

segments.pli: Nibbānogadhañhi, rādha, brahmacariyaṃ vussati, nibbānaparāyanaṃ nibbānapariyosānan”ti.
segments.en: For extinguishment is the culmination, destination, and end of the spiritual life.”

suttaplex.blurb: Rādha asks the Buddha about Māra, and the Buddha explains in terms of the five aggregates. Seeing in this way leads to freedom.
